Guided scaffolding

Source: R/scaffoldByFlipAndMerge.R
scaffoldByFlipAndMerge.Rd

Guided scaffolding

Usage

scaffoldByFlipAndMerge(gr, guide, drop = FALSE)

Arguments

gr

A GenomicRanges::GRanges object.

guide

A named list of data frames of contig names and orientations.

drop

Drop the contigs that were not included in the guide. The new sequence levels will be in the same order as in the guide.

See also

Other scaffolding functions: flipStrandNames(), longestMatchesInTarget(), mergeSeqLevels(), splitSeqLevel(), strandNames()

Author

Michael Mansfield

Charles Plessy

Examples

(gr <- GRanges(c("chrB:100-200:+", "chrC:201-300:+",
                 "chrB:301-400:+", "chrD:100-200:+")) |> forceSeqLengths())
#> GRanges object with 4 ranges and 0 metadata columns:
#>       seqnames    ranges strand
#>          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle>
#>   [1]     chrB   100-200      +
#>   [2]     chrC   201-300      +
#>   [3]     chrB   301-400      +
#>   [4]     chrD   100-200      +
#>   -------
#>   seqinfo: 3 sequences from an unspecified genome
(g <- list(
  chrD = data.frame(contig = "chrD", orientation = 1),
  chrBC = data.frame(contig = c("chrB", "chrC"), orientation = c(1,-1))))
#> $chrD
#>   contig orientation
#> 1   chrD           1
#> 
#> $chrBC
#>   contig orientation
#> 1   chrB           1
#> 2   chrC          -1
#> 

scaffoldByFlipAndMerge(gr, g, drop = TRUE)
#> GRanges object with 4 ranges and 0 metadata columns:
#>       seqnames    ranges strand
#>          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle>
#>   [1]     chrD   100-200      +
#>   [2]    chrBC   100-200      +
#>   [3]    chrBC   301-400      +
#>   [4]    chrBC   401-500      -
#>   -------
#>   seqinfo: 2 sequences from an unspecified genome
